instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related stud to differentiate between Akebia quinata (Thunb.) Decne. and Akebia trifoliata (Thunb.) Koidz.?
Output: Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was used to differentiate between Akebia quinata (Thunb.) Decne. and Akebia trifoliata (Thunb.) Koidz.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the related stud to differentiate between Akebia quinata (Thunb.) Decne. and Akebia trifoliata (Thunb.) Koidz.?
Output: Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy fingerprint was used to identify nine characteristic absorption peaks of the secondary metabolites of Akebia quinata (Thunb.) Decne. and Akebia trifoliata (Thunb.) Koidz.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the differentiating models, and how far can this metric go in predicting the origins of the stems in the related stud to differentiate between Akebia quinata (Thunb.) Decne. and Akebia trifoliata (Thunb.) Koidz.?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the differentiating models was the correct rate. The models were able to predict the origins of the stems of Akebia quinata (Thunb.) Decne. and Akebia trifoliata (Thunb.) Koidz. with a correct rate of 100% for Support Vector Machine, BP Neural Networks, and GA-BP Neural Networks, and 87.5% for Extreme Learning Machine.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the related study to differentiate between Akebia quinata (Thunb.) Decne. and Akebia trifoliata (Thunb.) Koidz.?
Output: The machine learning models used in the study to differentiate between Akebia quinata (Thunb.) Decne. and Akebia trifoliata (Thunb.) Koidz. were Support Vector Machine, BP Neural Networks, GA-BP Neural Networks, and Extreme Learning Machine.

instruction: Can the spectroscopic methods used in the study be considered superior to traditional methods for distinguishing between Akebia quinata (Thunb.) Decne. and Akebia trifoliata (Thunb.) Koidz.?
Output: Yes,based on the information provided in the text, it can be inferred that the spectroscopic methods used in the study, specifically Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), were effective in distinguishing between Akebia quinata (Thunb.) Decne. and Akebia trifoliata (Thunb.) Koidz. The FTIR spectroscopy fingerprint identified nine characteristic absorption peaks of the secondary metabolites of both varieties. This suggests that FTIR spectroscopy can be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for distinguishing between the two Akebia species.
